provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service and at other times as required, and submit additional reports within 10 days of written notice from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: This order terminates on June 7, 2031, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information collected.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified independent professional, covering the first 180 days after service and each two-year period thereafter for twenty years, and submit or retain these assessments as directed.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC all materials relied upon for Assessments for three years, and all other compliance-related documents for five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver copies of the order to current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least thirty days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, or change in name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within sixty days of service of the order, and submit additional written reports within ten days of written notice from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on June 15, 2031, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy or Security Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent its membership in, adherence to, or participation in any privacy or security program, including the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework and U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC all documents relating to compliance with the order for five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination

provisions.title: Compliance Notifications
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission of any changes in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, creation or dissolution of subsidiaries, bankruptcy filing, or change in corporate name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a true and accurate written report with the Commission detailing its compliance with the order, and submit additional reports upon request from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on June 19, 2034, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Information Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner the purposes, consumer controls, compliance program participation, or extent of collection and protection related to Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of filing, Respondent must instruct any Third Party that received Health Information from Respondent belonging to any Covered App User to destroy such information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Within 14 days of filing, Respondent must post the required notice Clearly and Conspicuously on its website and email it to all Covered App Users, with no additional materials included.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Before disclosing any consumer's Health Information to any Third Party, Respondent must provide clear and conspicuous disclosure of the categories, identities, and purposes of disclosure, and obtain affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Review
provisions.summary: Within 180 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must obtain an independent third-party Compliance Review of its privacy practices against the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield Principles, and submit it to the Commission within 10 days of completion.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with Compliance Reviewer
provisions.summary: Respondent must disclose all material facts to the Compliance Reviewer and must not misrepresent any fact material to the Reviewer's determination about Respondent's privacy practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Certification
provisions.summary: Within 180 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must submit a senior management certification to the Commission confirming establishment and maintenance of Order requirements and absence of known material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, Respondent must submit a report to the Commission detailing the date, facts, scope, number of affected consumers, remediation steps, and any notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies to key personnel for 5 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from recipients within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file sworn compliance reports annually for 5 years starting 60 days after issuance, submit notices of structural or contact changes within 14 days, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required materials electronically or by overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create certain records for 20 years and retain each for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance documentation, advertising materials, privacy-related representations, and Compliance Review materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission may monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC website and will terminate 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date a federal complaint alleging a violation is filed, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Ban on Disclosure of Health Information for Advertising Purposes
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from disclosing Health Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes, including advertising, marketing, or promoting products or services through third-party platforms.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Requirement to Obtain Affirmative Express Consent for Any Other Disclosure of Health Information
provisions.summary: Before disclosing any consumer's Health Information to any Third Party, Defendant must first obtain the relevant consumer's Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from misrepresenting its data collection, use, and disclosure practices, including misrepresentations about HIPAA compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Defendant must identify all Third Parties that received Covered Information without consent, notify them, instruct them to delete that information, and cease further disclosures to them pending confirmation of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Notice to Covered Users
provisions.summary: Defendant must email all Covered Users a court-mandated notice (Exhibit A) within 14 days of the effective date of the Order, without including any other materials with the notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive privacy program within 60 days, including written documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, employee training, data retention policies, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third-Party Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Privacy Program, covering the first year and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, with assessments completed within 60 days after each reporting period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Cooperation with Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing all Covered Information in its custody, and not misrepresenting any material facts to the Assessor.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide annual certifications from a senior corporate manager to the Commission for 10 years, attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty and Suspension
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $2,500,000 is entered against Defendant but suspended based on Defendant's financial representations; the suspension will be lifted if Defendant is found to have made material misstatements in its financial disclosures.

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Weight-Loss and Efficacy Claims
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any unsubstantiated weight-loss or efficacy claims about Covered Products unless supported by competent and reliable scientific evidence consisting of qualifying human clinical testing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Other Health-Related Claims
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any unsubstantiated representations about the health benefits, performance, or efficacy of any Covered Product beyond the weight-loss claims covered in Section I.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Tests, Studies, or Other Research
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting that any good or service's performance is scientifically proven, or misrepresenting the existence, contents, validity, results, or conclusions of any test, study, or research.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: FDA Approved Claims
provisions.summary: Nothing in this Order prohibits Defendants from making representations that are specifically approved or authorized in FDA labeling for Drugs or other products under applicable federal regulations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibitions on Review-Limiting Contract Provisions and Threats About Customer Communications
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from using non-disparagement contract terms, threatening customers about negative reviews, representing customers owe higher prices for speaking out, and retaliating against anyone who cooperates with law enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Deceptive Format in Advertising
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting that any website (including Gastricbypass.me) or other publication is an independent, objective resource for research or scientific information related to any good or service.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibitions Concerning Endorsements
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting endorser opinions or expertise, misrepresenting that endorsers are health professionals, and failing to clearly and conspicuously disclose material connections between endorsers and Defendants.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Prohibited Representations: Information Privacy
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting the extent to which they maintain the confidentiality of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: A judgment of $25,246,000 is entered jointly and severally against the Corporate Defendants and Individual Defendant Don Juravin for equitable monetary relief, with specific asset transfer requirements and directions for use of collected funds.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Lifting of Asset Freeze
provisions.summary: The Court's asset freeze is modified to permit the payments and transfers required by the Monetary Judgment section, and is fully dissolved upon completion of all such payments and transfers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide sufficient customer information to the FTC to facilitate consumer redress within 14 days of any written request, and are prohibited from disclosing, using, or benefitting from customer information obtained prior to entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Preservation of Records Relating to Competent and Reliable Human Clinical Tests or Studies
provisions.summary: Defendants must secure and preserve all underlying data and documents associated with any human clinical test or study upon which they rely to substantiate any claim covered by this Order, and must establish written procedures to protect participant information confidentiality.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of this Order to the FTC within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to all relevant personnel and business entities for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days from each recipient.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit sworn compliance reports to the FTC one year after entry of the Order, and for 20 years must submit sworn notices within 14 days of any change in contact information, business structure, or bankruptcy filings.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, covering accounting, personnel, compliance, consumer complaints, consumer communications, endorsements, and advertising materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through written requests for reports, depositions, document production, direct communication with Defendants and their employees, and undercover investigation, with Defendants required to respond within 14 days of written requests.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 53(b)), in connection with violations of Sections 5(a) and 12 of the FTC Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a) and 52)

provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers in connection with online advertising, marketing, or sales.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain biannual assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional certifying that their security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness to protect personal information.

provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC print or electronic copies of compliance-related documents, including documents contradicting compliance for five years and assessment-related materials for three years after each biennial assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and employees with managerial responsibilities, within 30 days of service for current personnel and within 30 days of assuming a position for future personnel.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, or name/address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on September 5, 2026, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a federal court complaint alleging any violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Deceptive Collection Practices
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained and enjoined from making any misrepresentation to consumers or third parties in connection with the collection of a debt, including false threats of arrest, overstated legal obligations, and false threats of lawsuits or wage garnishment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Unfair Collection Practices
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained and enjoined from engaging in any unfair act or practice in connection with the collection of a debt, including repeatedly calling consumers at work, using abusive language, and disclosing debts to third parties.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violations of the Truth In Lending Act and Regulation Z
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained and enjoined from failing to make required TILA disclosures clearly and conspicuously in writing before consummating consumer credit transactions, and from failing to comply with TILA and Regulation Z in any other manner.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violations of Nevada State Laws
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained and enjoined from violating Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, including requirements to obtain required licenses, provide notice of material facts, and comply with state and federal statutes governing the sale of goods or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Additional Disclosures and Other Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendants must clearly and conspicuously disclose material credit terms before consummating transactions, obtain written confirmation from consumers of receipt of disclosures, and provide written itemizations of amounts paid and due upon consumer request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Employee Monitoring by Defendants
provisions.summary: Defendants must take reasonable steps to monitor and ensure that all employees and independent contractors engaged in extending consumer credit or collecting debts comply with Sections I through V of this Order, including listening to calls, maintaining a customer response center, investigating complaints, and taking corrective action.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: Judgment of $1,000,000 is entered jointly and severally against all Defendants, with $970,125.00 paid to the FTC and $29,875.00 to the State of Nevada within 10 days of entry of this Order, to be used for equitable relief including consumer restitution.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor and investigate compliance with this Order by requiring Defendants to submit written reports, produce documents, appear for depositions, provide access to business locations, and by posing as consumers or suppliers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For a period of three years from entry of this Order, Defendants must notify the FTC of changes in residence, employment, business ownership, and corporate structure, and must file annual sworn compliance reports beginning 180 days after entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For a period of six years from entry of this Order, Defendants must create, retain, and secure records relating to consumer credit and debt collection, including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, marketing materials, and all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For a period of three years from entry of this Order, Corporate Defendants must deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, employees, agents, and representatives; Individual Defendants who control a business must do the same; and all recipients must sign dated acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receipt of the Order as entered by the Court.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Privacy Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy and confidentiality of covered information, or its participation in privacy or security compliance programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect the privacy and confidentiality of covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Third-Party Privacy Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial privacy assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records including privacy-related statements, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, compliance documents, and assessment materials for periods of five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees with supervisory responsibilities, and any business entity resulting from structural changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least thirty days prior to any change in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or change in corporate name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial compliance report with the Commission within sixty days after service of the order and submit additional reports within ten days of request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 30, 2032, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Consumer Control and Notice
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the options through which consumers can exercise control over data collection or the extent to which consumers will receive notice about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records related to compliance, representations, and consumer complaints for specified periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future personnel with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments for 10 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate changes that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file compliance reports with the Commission detailing compliance with this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 28, 2035, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or FTC files a complaint alleging violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Commission Order on Briefing Limits
provisions.summary: The Commission ordered that Respondent LabMD may not file an opening appeal brief but may file an answering brief not exceeding 21,000 words, and that Complaint Counsel may file a reply brief not exceeding 14,000 words, with specified deadlines.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting to U.S. consumers any aspect of their data practices, use of engager profiles, authenticity of user profiles, number of actual users, account deletion terms, third-party awards, or participation in privacy/security programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandated Data Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to their size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information collected.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Data Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party security assessments from a qualified professional (CISSP, CISA, or GIAC-certified), covering the first 180 days and each subsequent 2-year period for 20 years, with each assessment completed within 60 days of the reporting period end.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Partial Suspension
provisions.summary: A judgment of $8,750,000 is entered against Defendants jointly and severally; $828,500 must be paid within 7 days of entry, with additional remittance from a Directors' and Officers' Trust upon its termination; the remainder is suspended subject to conditions regarding truthfulness of financial representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to transferred assets, the Complaint's facts are established as true for future proceedings, and money paid may be used by the Commission for equitable relief including consumer redress.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from withholding customer information needed for Commission redress administration and from disclosing or misusing personal information obtained prior to entry of this Order, except for current customers in compliance with Section I.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver the Order to key personnel and new hires, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn compliance report 1 year after entry, provide sworn notices of material changes within 14 days for 20 years, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required materials via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting, personnel, consumer complaints, compliance documentation, and marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission has broad rights to monitor Defendants' compliance, including demanding reports and documents within 14 days, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendants and their personnel, and using undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Ban on Marketing Rental Listings
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently banned from advertising, marketing, promoting, offering, or selling subscriptions for or access to rental listing services, with a limited exception for properties Defendants personally own.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting any material aspect of any good or service they advertise or sell, including cost, restrictions, performance, refund/cancellation terms, or any other material fact.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: A judgment of $6,037,686.99 is entered jointly and severally against all Defendants for equitable monetary relief, to be used for consumer redress or deposited to the U.S. Treasury as disgorgement, with Defendants' taxpayer IDs available for collection purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to key personnel within 7 days (or before new personnel assume duties), and obtain signed acknowledgments from recipients within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order and sworn compliance notices within 14 days of specified changes for 20 years; must also report bankruptcy filings within 14 days, and must submit reports via specified methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting records, personnel records, and all records demonstrating full compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has broad authority to monitor compliance, including requesting sworn reports and documents within 14 days, conducting depositions, interviewing affiliated persons, and using undercover methods without prior notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they protect the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of Personal Information, including representations about collection/use/sharing, consumer control, and security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Data Security Program
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent and any business Individual Respondent controls must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written Information Security Program designed to address security risks to Covered Devices and protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified, independent professional, covering compliance with the Information Security Program requirements, and submit or retain them as specified.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Prior to collecting or disclosing any Covered Information, Respondents must clearly and conspicuously disclose the categories of information collected, identity of third-party recipients, and all purposes for collection/use/sharing, and must obtain the consumer's affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and new business entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports and timely notices of material changes (including structural changes, personnel changes for Individual Respondent, and bankruptcy filings) to the Commission, all sworn under penalty of perjury.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, representations about Personal Information, law enforcement communications, and assessment materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent-affiliated persons, and using any other lawful means including undercover investigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates on September 6, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of this Order in federal court, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Fake Documents
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from advertising, marketing, promoting, offering for sale, or assisting others in doing so with any Fake Document or any service, template, or mechanism for creating one.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Providing Means and Instrumentalities to Deceive Consumers
provisions.summary: Defendants and those acting in concert with them are permanently prohibited from providing others the means to make material misrepresentations about a person's identity, residency, finances, taxes, or employment, or about the authenticity of related documents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Suspension
provisions.summary: A $15,000 monetary judgment is entered jointly and severally against Defendants, but is suspended based on the truthfulness of their sworn financial statements; the suspension will be lifted if material misstatements are found.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after entry and notify the Commission within 14 days of specified changes for 20 years; Defendant must also notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and all submissions must follow specified format and delivery requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, covering accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints and refund requests, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through additional reports, depositions, document production, direct communications, interviews of affiliated persons, undercover methods, and consumer reporting agency records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Personal Information before transferring, selling, sharing, collecting, maintaining, or storing such information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain an initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, with specific assessor qualifications, reporting periods, and submission requirements.

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must disclose all material facts to the Assessor and must not misrepresent any fact material to the Assessor's determinations regarding the Information Security Program.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide the Commission with annual certifications from a senior corporate manager or officer attesting to compliance with the Order and disclosing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the Commission within 10 days of first notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, containing specified details about the incident.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: GLB Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Respondent and all associated persons with notice of this Order are permanently restrained and enjoined from violating any provision of the FTC's Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit its own acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, sworn notices of material changes within 14 days, and notice of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain for five years certain categories of records for 20 years after the Order issuance date, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy representations, assessment materials, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting sworn reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC website and terminates on September 3, 2039, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Prohibition on Dissemination of Intimate Images and Personal Information Posted Without Consent
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disseminating Intimate Images or Personal Information through a website or online service without providing clear and conspicuous notice to each depicted individual and obtaining their verifiable affirmative express written consent, including the right to revoke consent at any time.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Disposition of Personal Information and Intimate Images
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from selling, using, or otherwise benefitting from Personal Information or Intimate Images obtained without written consent, and must destroy all such material in his possession within 30 days of entry of this Order, except as required by law or government agency request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Prohibition on Charging Takedown Fees
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from charging any consumer any fee related to removing or taking down Personal Information or Intimate Images from any website, whether directly or through an intermediary.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Additional Conduct Prohibitions
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from setting up merchant processing accounts for any business entity unless he actually controls or has knowledge of its daily operations, and from serving as an officer, director, or manager of any entity unless he actually controls or has knowledge of its ordinary operations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Partial Suspension
provisions.summary: A judgment of $205,000 is entered against Defendant; $15,000 must be paid within 7 days of entry via electronic fund transfer, after which the remainder is suspended contingent on the accuracy of Defendant's financial representations. The suspension may be lifted if Defendant is found to have made material misstatements in those representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all interest in assets transferred under this Order; Complaint facts may be taken as true in future proceedings; money paid to the Commission may be used for equitable relief including consumer redress, with any remainder deposited to the U.S. Treasury as disgorgement.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Cooperation
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with Plaintiff representatives in this case and related investigations, including providing truthful information and appearing for interviews, depositions, hearings, and trials upon 5 days' written notice, without a subpoena.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain business records for 15 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaint records, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiffs are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through additional compliance reports, depositions, document production, direct communications, undercover testing, and consumer reporting agency records; Defendant must respond to written requests within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, its security or privacy practices, how it handles Personal Information or Health Information, its membership in any privacy/security programs, or any government approvals of its products or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Express Consent for Disclosure of Health Information to Third Parties
provisions.summary: Respondent must not disclose any Health Information to any Third Party unless it first obtains the Affirmative Express Consent of the individual identifiable by that Health Information, except as required by law.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Destruction of Saliva Samples
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must instruct laboratories to destroy retained physical DNA saliva samples held more than 180 days after Respondent accepted analysis results, and must provide sworn written confirmation of those instructions to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Personal Information, with specific minimum requirements including documentation, risk assessment, safeguards, testing, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, covering the first 180 days after the Order and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with assessments completed within 60 days after each reporting period and submitted to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Beginning one year after the Order's issuance and annually thereafter, Respondent must provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager or officer attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected or undisclosed material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the Commission within 10 days of notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, or within 10 business days of discovering unauthorized access to individually identifiable Health Information, including specified details about the incident.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $75,000 to the Commission within 8 days of the Order's effective date by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondent relinquishes all rights to transferred assets, agrees that Complaint facts may be taken as true in subsequent enforcement proceedings, and acknowledges the Commission's authority to use paid funds for consumer redress or related relief, with interest accruing on any default.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide sufficient customer information to enable the Commission to administer consumer redress to all Covered Customers, and must supply any additional redress-related information requested by the Commission within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel within 10 days (and before new personnel assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial compliance report on saliva sample destruction within 90 days, a comprehensive annual compliance report one year after issuance, compliance notices within 14 days of specified changes, and notice of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy/security representations, consent documents, Assessment materials, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports, records, and interviews, and may use other lawful means including posing as consumers or suppliers without prior notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Prevention of CSAM and NCM
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from misrepresenting the extent to which they review, remove, prevent, or protect consumers from CSAM and NCM on their Covered Services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Mandated Program to Prevent the Posting and Proliferation of CSAM and NCM
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and implement a comprehensive CSAM and NCM Prevention Program within 90 days, including documentation, governance, risk assessment, safeguards (age/consent verification, content review, removal processes), training, reporting tools, and biannual transparency reports.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party CSAM and NCM Prevention Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendants must cooperate fully with the CSAM and NCM Prevention Assessor by providing all relevant information, access to content management systems, and accurate disclosures without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.summary: Defendants must annually provide the FTC and the Division with a CEO certification attesting to compliance with Provisions I–V and disclosure of any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Notice to Users

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from misrepresenting how they collect, maintain, use, disclose, or protect Covered Information, or the control individuals have over their information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Privacy and Information Security Program, with specific assessor qualifications, reporting periods, assessment content requirements, and submission deadlines.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.summary: Defendants must cooperate fully with the Privacy and Security Assessor by providing all relevant information, network/IT asset visibility, and accurate disclosures without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Annual Certifications – Privacy and Information Security
provisions.summary: Defendants must annually provide the FTC and the Division with a senior officer certification attesting to compliance with the Order's requirements, no uncorrected noncompliance, and a description of all Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: A $15 million civil penalty judgment is entered in favor of the Utah Division; $5 million is due within 7 days of Order entry; the remaining $10 million is suspended conditional on compliance and may be reinstated upon contempt finding.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.
