provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security Products
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent, in connection with any security software product or service, either the extent to which the product reduces unauthorized access risk, or the extent to which it maintains, protects, or provides security or privacy features.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Performance of Security/Privacy Software
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the performance, benefits, or efficacy of any computer software product or service marketed as enhancing the security or privacy of any computer or similar system.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Consumer Refund Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide refunds to current InternetALERT subscribers by sending a refund notification email, posting a refund notice on their website, and issuing refund payments within seven days of receiving a request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Distribution of Order to Retailers and Affiliates
provisions.summary: Respondents must send a copy of this order by email to any retailer, affiliate, or other third party that advertises, promotes, offers for sale, sells, or distributes InternetALERT under an agreement with respondents.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must retain, for five years after the last dissemination of any covered representation, all advertisements, materials relied upon, and any tests or evidence that contradict or qualify the representation, and make them available to the FTC upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Distribution to Personnel
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days of service, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their role.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification — Bonzi Software, Inc.
provisions.summary: Bonzi Software, Inc. must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, or name/address change, by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director of Enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Individual Respondents' Employment Change Notification
provisions.summary: Joe Bonzi and Jay Bonzi must, for 10 years after entry of this order, notify the FTC of any discontinuance of their current business or employment and any affiliation with a new business or employment, by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director of Enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 120 days of service of this order, and at such other times as the FTC requires, detailing compliance with the order including a full description of the consumer redress program conducted under Part III.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: This order terminates on October 7, 2024, or 20 years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation of the order is filed in federal court by the U.S. or FTC, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Ban on Sale of Customer Phone Records
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from obtaining, marketing, or selling customer phone records and consumer personal information derived from customer phone records, with a narrow exception for records obtained pursuant to law, regulation, or lawful court order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendants are restrained from making false or deceptive statements to obtain consumer personal information and from requesting others to obtain such information through deceptive means.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Judgment is entered jointly and severally against Defendants for $2,700.00, to be paid by January 1, 2007, with funds deposited into an FTC-administered fund for equitable relief.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Cooperation with FTC
provisions.summary: Defendant Edmund Edmister must cooperate in good faith with the FTC, appearing for interviews, depositions, and other proceedings related to the complaint upon written request, without requiring a subpoena.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendants must deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, and agents, with delivery within 5 days for current personnel and prior to start for new personnel, and must obtain signed receipt acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendants must create and retain specified business records — including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, marketing materials, third-party records, and Order acknowledgments — for any business they majority own or control that deals in consumer personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendants must notify the FTC of changes in residence, employment, corporate structure, and other specified matters; and must file a sworn compliance report 180 days after entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, site inspections, undercover posing, and interviews of Defendants' personnel; Defendants must cooperate within 14 days of written notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit to the FTC a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of the Order within five business days after receipt of the entered Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting any material facts about how their file-sharing application operates, including which files will be shared, with whom, and how consumers can control sharing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Required Disclosures and Defaults Relating to the Sharing of Downloaded Files
provisions.summary: Defendants may not distribute any file-sharing application unless it clearly discloses sharing behavior before installation, requires affirmative consumer selection of files to share, and provides easy mechanisms to disable sharing after installation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Requirements Relating to User-Originated Files and Default Settings
provisions.summary: Defendants may not distribute any file-sharing application capable of sharing user-originated files unless sharing of such files can only be enabled after complete installation, with clear disclosures, affirmative consumer selection, and easy mechanisms to reverse sharing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Requirements Regarding Legacy Versions
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from promoting, selling, or distributing any Legacy Version of FrostWire Desktop or FrostWire for Android, and must transmit update code and prominent notices to all computers running Legacy Versions within ten business days of the order's entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, facility inspections, undercover investigations, and employee interviews.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For three years, Individual Defendant must notify the FTC of changes in residence, employment, and name; all Defendants must notify the FTC of corporate structure changes; Defendants must file a sworn compliance report 60 days after entry; and Defendants must notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 15 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: For six years from entry of this Order, each Defendant must create and retain specified business records, including accounting records, personnel records, complaints, compliance documents, and executable copies of all versions of any file-sharing application they distribute.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendants must deliver copies of this Order to principals, officers, managers, employees, and agents, and obtain signed and dated acknowledgments of receipt within thirty days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receipt of the Order as entered by the Court.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy and confidentiality of covered information, or misrepresent its participation in any privacy or compliance program such as the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Disclosure and Consent Before New Sharing of User Information
provisions.summary: Before any new or additional sharing of a Google user's identified information with third parties that represents a change from stated practices at the time of collection and results from a product or service change, respondent must clearly and prominently disclose the sharing and obtain express affirmative consent from the user.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Comprehensive Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written privacy program designed to address privacy risks in product development and to protect the privacy and confidentiality of covered information, including specific organizational, risk assessment, control, vendor management, and evaluation components.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Initial and Biennial Third-Party Privacy Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party privacy assessments from a qualified professional with at least three years of experience in privacy and data protection, approved by the FTC, covering specified content and delivered within defined timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC upon request various records related to privacy statements, consumer complaints, compliance documents, and assessment materials for specified retention periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and employees or agents with supervisory responsibilities related to the order's subject matter, within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least thirty days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, mergers, name changes, or bankruptcy filings, with notice sent by certified mail.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within ninety days of service of the order, and submit additional written reports within ten days of written request by the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on October 13, 2031, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC or United States files a complaint alleging a violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, confidentiality, or security of personal information collected from or about consumers.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on September 29, 2035, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.

provisions.summary: Respondent must acknowledge receipt of the Order itself, deliver copies to relevant personnel and business successors for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients.

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial sworn compliance report within 60 days, and thereafter submit timely sworn notices of changes in contact points, business structure, or bankruptcy proceedings.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after issuance and retain each record for 5 years, covering financial, personnel, compliance, and advertising materials.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance through information requests, direct communications, interviews of affiliated persons, and undercover investigations.

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC website and terminates on November 15, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or Commission files a complaint alleging any Order violation in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent and associated persons must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the extent to which it monitors or audits internal access to consumers' Personal Information, or the extent to which it protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect Personal Information, including designated personnel, risk assessments, controls, service provider oversight, and ongoing program evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party privacy assessments by a qualified, independent professional with at least 3 years of experience, approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, with each assessment completed within 60 days after the reporting period and provided to the Commission within 10 days of completion.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the FTC within a reasonable time after discovering a Covered Incident, but no later than 10 days after first notifying any U.S. government entity, detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of consumers, remediation steps, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days of the Order's effective date, deliver copies of the Order to principals, relevant employees, agents, and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after the Order's issuance and sworn notices within 14 days of changes in designated contacts, corporate structure, or bankruptcy filings; all submissions must be sworn under penalty of perjury and submitted via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance date and retain each for 5 years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, privacy representations, assessment materials, bug bounty reports, law enforcement communications, and records contradicting compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover approaches.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on October 25, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — Continuation
provisions.summary: The original Permanent Injunction remains in full force and effect, except that Sections VI through IX are replaced by Sections V through VIII of this Amended Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Consumer Redress
provisions.summary: A judgment of $100,000,000 is entered against LifeLock; LifeLock must deposit the full amount into the Court's Registry within five business days and satisfy all related obligations governing disbursement, crediting, and remittance to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: LifeLock must provide customer information requested by the Commission to facilitate consumer redress, including responding to written requests within 10 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Entry of Order
provisions.summary: The court finds no just reason for delay and directs the clerk to enter the Order immediately.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must notify the Commission of corporate changes at least 30 days in advance, file annual sworn compliance reports, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 15 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor LifeLock's compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, site inspections, undercover investigations, and employee interviews, using all lawful means including civil discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: LifeLock must create and retain specified categories of records for defined periods: 13 years from the Permanent Injunction for business and compliance records, 3 years for biennial assessment materials, and 5 years from this Order for consumer redress payment records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must deliver copies of the Permanent Injunction and this Order to principals, officers, relevant employees, agents, and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgement of Receipt of This Order
provisions.summary: LifeLock must submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for all purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in or Compliance with Privacy Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner its membership in, adherence to, compliance with, or participation in any government- or self-regulatory-sponsored privacy or security program, including the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Requirement for Annual Outside Compliance Review
provisions.summary: While self-certified under Privacy Shield, Respondent must obtain an annual outside compliance review from an FTC-approved independent third-party assessor demonstrating that its Privacy Shield assertions are true and properly implemented; a signed verification statement must be available to the Commission upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Requirement to Meet Continuing Obligations Under Privacy Shield
provisions.summary: Upon any withdrawal or lapse in Privacy Shield certification, Respondent must affirm to the Department of Commerce within 30 days and annually thereafter that it will either continue applying Privacy Shield Principles, protect the information by another EU/Swiss-authorized means, or return or delete the information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an acknowledgment of receipt to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and any successor entities (within 10 days for current personnel, before assuming responsibilities for others), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a sworn initial compliance report within 60 days, submit sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, ensure all sworn submissions comply with 28 U.S.C. § 1746, and route all submissions to the FTC via the specified email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 10 years and retain each for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, full compliance records, and copies of all representations subject to the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor compliance by requiring sworn reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover contacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective 60 days after service and terminates on October 28, 2040, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner their collection, maintenance, use, deletion, or disclosure of Personal Information, or the extent to which they protect the privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 180 days of the effective date, encompassing risk assessments, safeguards, training, incident response, access controls, encryption, vulnerability management, vendor oversight, and franchisee requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program from a qualified, independent assessor, covering the first 365 days and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, and submit assessments to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the Third-Party Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing all material facts, and not misrepresenting any fact material to the assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide an annual CEO certification to the FTC confirming compliance with the Order and disclosing any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC including incident dates, causes, types of information affected, number of consumers impacted, remediation steps taken, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Loyalty Rewards Program Accounts Review
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide U.S. consumers a clear and conspicuous method to request review of their Loyalty Rewards Program account for unauthorized activity within the preceding 12 months, and restore points lost to unauthorized third-party activity.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Data Handling
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide a clear deletion request process for U.S. consumers within 180 days, maintain a data retention policy limiting retention to what is reasonably necessary, and disclose the purpose of data collection in their terms of use or privacy policy.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant officers, directors, employees, and agents, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide compliance notices within 14 days of any designated contact or structural changes, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days, and submit all filings via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each record for 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy representations, third-party assessment materials, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has the authority to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondents' affiliates, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Ban on Use of Information from Sentry
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing Collected Information to anyone other than Personnel Necessary to Support Sentry or a Registered Sentry User for the sole purpose of accessing that user's account.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Destruction of Collected Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must destroy, within 5 days of entry of the Order, any Collected Information transferred to or available in any database or server used by Pulse, except for information only available to Registered Sentry Users.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must notify the FTC of structural changes for 4 years, submit sworn annual compliance reports starting 60 days after entry, notify of bankruptcy within 15 days, and send all reports by overnight courier or first-class mail with simultaneous electronic copy.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor and investigate Defendant's compliance, including requiring written reports, document production, depositions, and facility access, as well as using discovery procedures and posing as consumers or suppliers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain for seven years specific records related to Sentry and Pulse, including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, advertising materials, and all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must deliver copies of the Order to principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and successor business entities within specified timeframes, and must obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the FTC acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Use of Facial Recognition or Analysis Systems Prohibited
provisions.summary: Respondents are prohibited for five years from deploying or using any Facial Recognition or Analysis System in any retail store, retail pharmacy, or online retail platform.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Deletion of Covered Biometric Information
provisions.summary: Respondents must delete all photos, videos, and derived data used in connection with Facial Recognition or Analysis Systems prior to the order's effective date, notify third parties to do the same, and provide written confirmations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System Monitoring Program
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System (other than prohibited facial recognition), Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Monitoring Program to identify and address consumer risks, including risks of disproportionate harm based on race, ethnicity, gender, sex, age, or disability.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandatory Notice and Complaint Procedures for Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must establish and maintain procedures to provide consumers with notice of Gallery enrollment and of adverse actions taken based on Outputs, and must investigate and respond to consumer complaints within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Required Retention Limits for Biometric Information
provisions.summary: Prior to implementing any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must develop and implement a written retention schedule for each type of consumer Biometric Information collected, specifying purposes, a deletion timeframe of no more than five years, and the basis for that timeframe.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Disclosure of Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of the effective date, Respondents must post Clear and Conspicuous notices in each physical retail location and on each website, mobile application, or online service disclosing the use of any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, including types of Biometric Information collected, types of Outputs generated, purposes for use, and retention timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information, including misrepresentations about security measures, privacy choices, data collection/use/deletion practices, or third-party access.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of the effective date, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information, encompassing documentation, board reporting, designated leadership, risk assessments, safeguards, vendor management, and ongoing evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of the Information Security Program from a qualified Assessor approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days after the Program is established and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with detailed assessment requirements and submission obligations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from their CEO (or designated senior officer) confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents affecting 100 or more consumers during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a report to the Commission detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of affected consumers, remediation actions taken, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit their own acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to current and future principals, officers, relevant employees, subsidiaries, and agents for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an initial sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, and submit all required documents to the Commission via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after the issuance date and retain each for five years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, privacy/security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement communications, and records of non-compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions, obtaining records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing affiliated individuals, and using all other lawful means including undercover operations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes the Commission's prior 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and will terminate 20 years from the date of issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or Commission files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Google must pay a civil penalty of $22.5 million to the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Cookie Deletion Systems
provisions.summary: Until February 15, 2014, Google must maintain systems that delete Google cookies from Safari browser users.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Google must report to the FTC within twenty days after February 15, 2014, demonstrating compliance with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(1) and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(1) and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in Privacy or Security Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any way its membership in, compliance with, or participation in any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or self-regulatory organization, including the EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield frameworks.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.summary: Respondent must acknowledge receipt of the Order itself, deliver copies to relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified business records for 20 years after the issuance date, with each record retained for at least 5 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting reports and records, conducting interviews of affiliated persons, and using other lawful means including undercover contacts.
